Abstract:
EpichloÃ« endophytes and their anamorphic relatives,
Neotyphodium endophytes, are fungal symbionts of grasses, ubiquitously
existing all over the world. However, up to now only a few species were
reported, especially associated with the native grasses. Leymus
chinensis is a dominant grass in the Inner Mongolia steppe, China.
Previously it was reported that L. chinensis was infected by endophytes,
but little was known about these endophytes. In the present study, 96
fungal isolates were obtained from three populations of L. chinensis.
They were classified into three morphotypes based on growth rate and
morphological characters including colonial morphology, the production
of conidiogenous cells, conidial size and dimension on potato dextrose
agar medium. All the tub2, tef1 and act1 sequences identified only a
single product in all representative isolates from morphotype I. Based
on both morphological and phylogenetic analyses, isolates in morphotype
I were described as representing a novel EpichloÃ« species, EpichloÃ«
chinensis sp. nov. Isolates in both morphotype II and III were
identified as Acremonium spp. and Fusarium spp., separately.
